Gibbs’ son carried on his legacy, serving multiple terms in the Florida House of Representatives, but his legacy also lives on today in Florida A&M University, which he helped to establish. A powerful and growing inheritance. #BlackHistoryMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FLPvrioVQAUlrqp.jpg

During his time in office, he led investigations into the KKK and other criminals. He was also active on the Board of Education, and after his term ended he served as Florida Superintendent of Public Instruction and as a Tallahassee City Councilman.

Though he unsuccessfully ran for a seat in the Florida House of Representatives, he was appointed Secretary of State under Gov. Harrison Reed. The position was seen as ceremonial. He made it proactive.
He became more involved in politics. He was one of eighteen African American delegates to the 1868 Florida Constitutional Convention.
After the war Gibbs felt called to move south to help newly freed slaves. Eventually, he arrived in Florida in 1867 and started a private school in Jacksonville.

He became a prominent abolitionist, working with Frederick Douglass and others, writing for anti-slavery publications, and serving as Pastor for the First African Presbyterian Church in Philadelphia. He called for equal treatment on the rail cars and accommodations.

Born in Philadelphia in 1821, Gibbs worked as a carpenter’s apprentice before he attended Dartmouth College, the third Black man to do so. He later attended Princeton Theological Seminary to become a minister.

Jonathan Clarkson Gibbs was a pastor, abolitionist, and Florida’s first and only Black Secretary of State. He also helped to build the state's education system, including leadership to establish @FAMU_1887 (#FAMU #FAMUly #Rattlers #FangsUp🐍). #BlackHistoryMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FLQZkozXIAA82EX.jpg

That is why I introduced a resolution to condemn the actions of the white supremacist mobs, honor the memory of the victims, and create a national day of remembrance for Black Americans that were victims of forced migrations throughout our Nation's history.

Property theft from Black landowners as well as the displacement caused by terrorizing Black residents of Forsyth County demonstrates how deeply racism and injustice have contributed to persistent wealth inequality between Black and white Americans throughout our history.
Unfortunately, Forsyth County's story is not unique. It is only one of many such atrocities that exemplifies the lasting impact of white supremacy in our Nation.

If the goal is to determine whether hydrogen is a viable alternative to some of our existing energy technologies, we cannot discount a method that could drive the need for, and development of, other parts of the supply chain.

At least 58 Black landowners in Forsyth County had their property stolen were forced to sell their land under the threat of lynching, arson, and mob violence. Many poor Black residents were driven from their homes and sought refuge in cities far from Forsyth.

“Night Riders” proceeded to ride on horseback throughout Forsyth County terrorizing families and burning Black churches and businesses. Afterwards, the entire Black population of Forsyth County was forced out, with little to no Black residents in the county for nearly a century.

Rob Edwards was dragged from his jail cell and lynched in the town square of Cumming, Georgia. Oscar Daniel and Ernest Knowx were denied due process, convicted in a one-day trial, and publicly hanged shortly thereafter.

Over 111 years ago, Mae Crow, an 18-year old white woman, was murdered. Her crime remains unsolved today. Three black residents, Rob Edwards, Ernest Knox, and Oscar Daniel were immediately accused of Mae Crow's murder, without due process.

In 1912, over 1,100 Black Americans in Forsyth County, Georgia were threatened, intimidated, and driven out by white supremacist mobs. Yesterday, I introduced a resolution to recognize those individuals and uplift the voices of their descendants. #Thread
